mn57:0.2.eng: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

mn57:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā koliyesu viharati haliddavasanaṃ nāma koliyānaṃ nigamo.
mn57:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Koliyans, where they have a town named Haliddavasana.
mn57:1.2.comm: The Koliyans were south-eastern neighbors of the Sakyans, with whom they had close ties in marriage and customs. | Haliddavasana (“yellow-clothes”) is also the scene of SN 46.54, which discusses similarities and differences between Buddhism and wanderers when it comes to meditation.

mn57:2.1.pli: Atha kho puṇṇo ca koliyaputto govatiko acelo ca seniyo kukkuravatiko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā puṇṇo koliyaputto govatiko bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Acelo pana seniyo kukkuravatiko bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā kukkurova palikujjitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn57:2.1.eng: Then Puṇṇa the Koliyan, a cow votary, and the naked ascetic Seniya, a dog votary, went to see the Buddha. Puṇṇa bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side, while Seniya exchanged greetings and polite conversation with him before sitting down to one side curled up like a dog.
mn57:2.1.comm: The cow votary (govatika) is attested in Sanskrit (eg. Mahābhārata 5.97.13). Elsewhere, non-Buddhist texts mention cat votaries (Manu 4.30), snake votaries, fish votaries, those who live like beasts (mṛgacaryā), and others, but not, so far as I am aware, dog votaries. The cow and dog observances are found in later Buddhist texts (Yogacārabhūmi 157.10, Mahākarmavibhaṅga 44.19, Śikṣāsamuccaya 332.3, etc.) evidently drawing from this sutta. Thus, while no parallel of this sutta has survived, it was known in northern Buddhist traditions and must have been lost due to a failure of transmission.

mn57:2.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho puṇṇo koliyaputto govatiko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

mn57:2.3.pli: “ayaṃ, bhante, acelo seniyo kukkuravatiko dukkarakārako chamānikkhittaṃ bhojanaṃ bhuñjati.
mn57:2.3.eng: “Sir, this naked ascetic Seniya the dog votary does a hard thing: he eats food placed on the ground.

mn57:2.4.pli: Tassa taṃ kukkuravataṃ dīgharattaṃ samattaṃ samādinnaṃ.
mn57:2.4.eng: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a dog.

mn57:2.5.eng: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”

mn57:2.6.pli: “Alaṃ, puṇṇa, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī”ti.
mn57:2.6.eng: “Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”

mn57:2.8.pli: tatiyampi kho puṇṇo koliyaputto govatiko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn57:2.8.eng: and a third time, Puṇṇa said to the Buddha,

mn57:2.9.pli: “ayaṃ, bhante, acelo seniyo kukkuravatiko dukkarakārako chamānikkhittaṃ bhojanaṃ bhuñjati.
mn57:2.9.eng: “Sir, this naked ascetic Seniya does a hard thing: he eats food placed on the ground.

mn57:2.10.pli: Tassa taṃ kukkuravataṃ dīgharattaṃ samattaṃ samādinnaṃ.
mn57:2.10.eng: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a dog.

mn57:2.11.eng: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”

mn57:2.12.pli: “Addhā kho te ahaṃ, puṇṇa, na labhāmi.
mn57:2.12.eng: “Clearly, Puṇṇa, I’m not getting through to you when I say:

mn57:2.13.pli: Alaṃ, puṇṇa, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchīti;
mn57:2.13.eng: ‘Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’

mn57:3.1.pli: Idha, puṇṇa, ekacco kukkuravataṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkurasīlaṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkuracittaṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkurākappaṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ.
mn57:3.1.eng: Take someone who develops the dog observance fully and uninterruptedly. They develop a dog’s ethics, a dog’s mentality, and a dog’s behavior fully and uninterruptedly.

mn57:3.2.pli: So kukkuravataṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkurasīlaṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkuracittaṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkurākappaṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā kukkurānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
mn57:3.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of dogs.

mn57:3.3.pli: Sace kho panassa evaṃdiṭṭhi hoti: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti, sāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi.
mn57:3.3.eng: But if they have such a view: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’ This is their wrong view.

mn57:3.4.pli: Micchādiṭṭhissa kho ahaṃ, puṇṇa, dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi—nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā.
mn57:3.4.eng: An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say: hell or the animal realm.

mn57:3.5.pli: Iti kho, puṇṇa, sampajjamānaṃ kukkuravataṃ kukkurānaṃ sahabyataṃ upaneti, vipajjamānaṃ nirayan”ti.
mn57:3.5.eng: So if the dog observance succeeds it leads to rebirth in the company of dogs, but if it fails it leads to hell.”

mn57:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, acelo seniyo kukkuravatiko parodi, assūni pavattesi.
mn57:4.1.eng: When he said this, Seniya cried and burst out in tears.

mn57:4.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā puṇṇaṃ koliyaputtaṃ govatikaṃ etadavoca:

mn57:4.3.eng: “This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said:

mn57:4.4.pli: Alaṃ, puṇṇa, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī”ti.
mn57:4.4.eng: ‘Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”

mn57:4.5.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhante, etaṃ rodāmi yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāha;
mn57:4.5.eng: Seniya said, “Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said.

mn57:4.6.pli: api ca me idaṃ, bhante, kukkuravataṃ dīgharattaṃ samattaṃ samādinnaṃ.
mn57:4.6.eng: But, sir, for a long time I have undertaken this observance to behave like a dog.

mn57:4.7.eng: Sir, this Puṇṇa is a cow votary.

mn57:4.8.pli: Tassa taṃ govataṃ dīgharattaṃ samattaṃ samādinnaṃ.
mn57:4.8.eng: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a cow.
mn57:4.8.comm: From a text of a later date, the cow observance is described thus: “One should bathe in the urine of a cow, maintain himself with milk, and move with the cows, eating after they had eaten. It is known as govrata. One would become free from the sins in a month. He would attain the world of cows and reach heaven” (Agni Purāna 292:12–13a, Gangadharan’s translation). This is not a penance for burning off sin, but rather a way of elevating oneself through the sacred nature of the cow. It is not clear, however, if this is the same as the observance in the Buddha’s day.

mn57:4.9.eng: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”

mn57:4.10.pli: “Alaṃ, seniya, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī”ti.
mn57:4.10.eng: “Enough, Seniya, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”

mn57:4.12.pli: tatiyampi kho acelo seniyo kukkuravatiko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn57:4.12.eng: and a third time Seniya said to the Buddha,

mn57:4.13.eng: “Sir, this Puṇṇa is a cow votary.

mn57:4.14.pli: Tassa taṃ govataṃ dīgharattaṃ samattaṃ samādinnaṃ.
mn57:4.14.eng: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a cow.

mn57:4.15.eng: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”

mn57:4.16.pli: “Addhā kho te ahaṃ, seniya, na labhāmi.
mn57:4.16.eng: “Clearly, Seniya, I’m not getting through to you when I say:

mn57:4.17.pli: Alaṃ, seniya, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchīti;
mn57:4.17.eng: ‘Enough, Seniya, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’

mn57:5.1.pli: Idha, seniya, ekacco govataṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, gosīlaṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, gocittaṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, gavākappaṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ.
mn57:5.1.eng: Take someone who develops the cow observance fully and uninterruptedly. They develop a cow’s ethics, a cow’s mentality, and a cow’s behavior fully and uninterruptedly.

mn57:5.2.pli: So govataṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, gosīlaṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, gocittaṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, gavākappaṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā gunnaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
mn57:5.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of cows.
mn57:5.2.comm: This means to be reborn as a cow, rather than in the goloka, which in Hinduism is a heaven for cows.

mn57:5.3.pli: Sace kho panassa evaṃdiṭṭhi hoti: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti, sāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi.
mn57:5.3.eng: But if they have such a view: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’ This is their wrong view.

mn57:5.4.pli: Micchādiṭṭhissa kho ahaṃ, seniya, dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi—nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā.
mn57:5.4.eng: An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say: hell or the animal realm.

mn57:5.5.pli: Iti kho, seniya, sampajjamānaṃ govataṃ gunnaṃ sahabyataṃ upaneti, vipajjamānaṃ nirayan”ti.
mn57:5.5.eng: So if the cow observance succeeds it leads to rebirth in the company of cows, but if it fails it leads to hell.”

mn57:6.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, puṇṇo koliyaputto govatiko parodi, assūni pavattesi.
mn57:6.1.eng: When he said this, Puṇṇa cried and burst out in tears.

mn57:6.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acelaṃ seniyaṃ kukkuravatikaṃ etadavoca:

mn57:6.3.eng: “This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said:

mn57:6.4.pli: Alaṃ, seniya, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī”ti.
mn57:6.4.eng: ‘Enough, Seniya, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”

mn57:6.5.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhante, etaṃ rodāmi yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāha;
mn57:6.5.eng: Puṇṇa said, “Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said.

mn57:6.6.pli: api ca me idaṃ, bhante, govataṃ dīgharattaṃ samattaṃ samādinnaṃ.
mn57:6.6.eng: But, sir, for a long time I have undertaken this observance to behave like a cow.

mn57:6.7.eng: I am quite confident that the Buddha

mn57:6.8.pli: pahoti bhagavā tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ yathā ahaṃ cevimaṃ govataṃ pajaheyyaṃ, ayañceva acelo seniyo kukkuravatiko taṃ kukkuravataṃ pajaheyyā”ti.
mn57:6.8.eng: is capable of teaching me so that I can give up this cow observance, and the naked ascetic Seniya can give up that dog observance.”

mn57:6.9.pli: “Tena hi, puṇṇa, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn57:6.9.eng: “Well then, Puṇṇa, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn57:6.10.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho puṇṇo koliyaputto govatiko bhagavato paccassosi.

mn57:7.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, puṇṇa, kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
mn57:7.1.eng: “Puṇṇa, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight.

mn57:7.3.eng: There are dark deeds with dark results;

mn57:7.5.eng: dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results; and
mn57:7.5.comm: By treating ethical decisions via a tetralemma, the Buddha rejects the “law of the excluded middle” and the consequent belief that acts must be either right or wrong.

mn57:7.6.pli: atthi, puṇṇa, kammaṃ akaṇhaṃ asukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ, kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
mn57:7.6.eng: neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.
mn57:7.6.comm: These are the intentions associated with the noble eightfold path.

mn57:8.1.eng: And what are dark deeds with dark results?

mn57:8.2.pli: Idha, puṇṇa, ekacco sabyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
mn57:8.2.eng: It’s when someone makes hurtful choices by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn57:8.3.pli: So sabyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn57:8.3.eng: Having made these choices, they’re reborn in a hurtful world,

mn57:8.4.pli: Tamenaṃ sabyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ samānaṃ sabyābajjhā phassā phusanti.

mn57:8.5.pli: So sabyābajjhehi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno sabyābajjhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti ekantadukkhaṃ, seyyathāpi sattā nerayikā.
mn57:8.5.eng: Touched by hurtful contacts, they experience hurtful feelings that are exclusively painful—like the beings in hell.

mn57:8.6.pli: Iti kho, puṇṇa, bhūtā bhūtassa upapatti hoti;
mn57:8.6.eng: This is how a being is born from a being.

mn57:8.7.eng: For your deeds determine your rebirth,

mn57:8.8.eng: and when you’re reborn contacts strike you.

mn57:8.9.eng: This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.

mn57:8.10.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, puṇṇa, kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ.
mn57:8.10.eng: These are called dark deeds with dark results.

mn57:9.1.eng: And what are bright deeds with bright results?

mn57:9.2.pli: Idha, puṇṇa, ekacco abyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, abyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, abyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
mn57:9.2.eng: It’s when someone makes pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn57:9.3.pli: So abyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, abyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, abyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā abyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn57:9.3.eng: Having made these choices, they are reborn in a pleasing world,

mn57:9.4.pli: Tamenaṃ abyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ samānaṃ abyābajjhā phassā phusanti.

mn57:9.5.pli: So abyābajjhehi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno abyābajjhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti ekantasukhaṃ, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
mn57:9.5.eng: Touched by pleasing contacts, they experience pleasing feelings of perfect happiness—like the gods of universal beauty.

mn57:9.6.pli: Iti kho, puṇṇa, bhūtā bhūtassa upapatti hoti;
mn57:9.6.eng: This is how a being is born from a being.

mn57:9.7.eng: For your deeds determine your rebirth,

mn57:9.8.eng: and when you’re reborn contacts strike you.

mn57:9.9.eng: This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.

mn57:9.10.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, puṇṇa, kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ.
mn57:9.10.eng: These are called bright deeds with bright results.

mn57:10.1.eng: And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results?

mn57:10.2.pli: Idha, puṇṇa, ekacco sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
mn57:10.2.eng: It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn57:10.3.pli: So sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn57:10.3.eng: Having made these choices, they are reborn in a world that is both hurtful and pleasing,

mn57:10.4.pli: Tamenaṃ sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi lokaṃ upapannaṃ samānaṃ sabyābajjhāpi abyābajjhāpi phassā phusanti.
mn57:10.4.eng: where hurtful and pleasing contacts strike them.

mn57:10.5.pli: So sabyābajjhehipi abyābajjhehipi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vedanaṃ vedeti vokiṇṇasukhadukkhaṃ, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
mn57:10.5.eng: Touched by both hurtful and pleasing contacts, they experience both hurtful and pleasing feelings that are a mixture of pleasure and pain—like humans, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

mn57:10.6.pli: Iti kho, puṇṇa, bhūtā bhūtassa upapatti hoti;
mn57:10.6.eng: This is how a being is born from a being.

mn57:10.7.eng: For what you do brings about your rebirth,

mn57:10.8.eng: and when you’re reborn contacts strike you.

mn57:10.9.eng: This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.

mn57:10.10.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, puṇṇa, kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ.
mn57:10.10.eng: These are called dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.

mn57:11.1.pli: Katamañca, puṇṇa, kammaṃ akaṇhaṃ asukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ, kammakkhayāya saṃvattati?
mn57:11.1.eng: And what are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds?

mn57:11.2.pli: Tatra, puṇṇa, yamidaṃ kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ tassa pahānāya yā cetanā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ tassa pahānāya yā cetanā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ tassa pahānāya yā cetanā—
mn57:11.2.eng: It’s the intention to give up dark deeds with dark results, bright deeds with bright results, and both dark and bright deeds with both dark and bright results.

mn57:11.3.pli: idaṃ vuccati, puṇṇa, kammaṃ akaṇhaṃ asukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ, kammakkhayāya saṃvattatīti.
mn57:11.3.eng: These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

mn57:11.4.pli: Imāni kho, puṇṇa, cattāri kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
mn57:11.4.eng: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

mn57:12.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, puṇṇo koliyaputto govatiko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn57:12.1.eng: When he had spoken, Puṇṇa the Koliyan said to the Buddha,

mn57:12.4.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn57:12.4.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
mn57:12.4.comm: Puṇṇa the layman goes for refuge, while Seniya the ascetic goes forth.

mn57:13.1.pli: Acelo pana seniyo kukkuravatiko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn57:13.1.eng: And Seniya the naked ascetic said to the Buddha,

mn57:13.4.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn57:13.4.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn57:13.5.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
mn57:13.5.eng: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
mn57:13.5.comm: In the early period, there was no distinction between “going forth” (pabbajjā) and “ordination” (upasampadā). They refer to two sides of the same coin: leaving the home life and entering the ascetic life. Ordination was originally granted by the Buddha with the simple call, “Come mendicant!” (Kd 1:6.32.1). As the community grew, the Buddha authorized the Saṅgha to perform the “going forth and ordination” (Kd 1:12.1.1). Later still, the novice (sāmaṇera) platform was introduced for teenagers and became known as “going forth” (Kd 1:54.3.2). Finally, the novice ordination was standardized for all ordinands, even if it was a mere preliminary for the “full ordination”.

mn57:14.1.pli: “Yo kho, seniya, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṃ so cattāro māse parivasati. Catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya.
mn57:14.1.eng: “Seniya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.
mn57:14.1.comm: This probation is laid down in the Vinaya at Kd 1:38.1.5. The candidate shaves, dons the robes, takes refuge, and asks for probation. They must show good conduct and restraint, diligence in duties, and enthusiasm for the Buddha’s teachings and practice.

mn57:14.2.eng: However, I recognize individual differences in this matter.”
mn57:14.2.comm: In addition to individual exceptions, there are general exceptions for dreadlocked fire-worshipping ascetics, since they believe in kamma, and for the Buddha’s relatives (Kd 1:38.11.3).

mn57:14.3.pli: “Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhantā pabbajjaṃ ākaṅkhantā upasampadaṃ te cattāro māse parivasanti catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya, ahaṃ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi catunnaṃ vassānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu, upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā”ti.
mn57:14.3.eng: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”

mn57:15.1.pli: Alattha kho acelo seniyo kukkuravatiko bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
mn57:15.1.eng: And the naked ascetic Seniya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

mn57:15.2.pli: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā seniyo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, Tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
mn57:15.2.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Seniya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn57:15.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
mn57:15.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

mn57:15.4.pli: Aññataro kho panāyasmā seniyo arahataṃ ahosīti.
mn57:15.4.eng: And Venerable Seniya became one of the perfected.
